pros: A great institution founded on the basis of broadening the educational reach of our worlds future... the avenues created by the professors to the students has so much potential to make this world a greater place. cons: People think that they can leave legacies and try to make a name for themselves by stepping on fellow employees, taking every opportunity provided to make themselves look better. pros: Pay for non-TT positions is higher than average. Support for TT faculty is generally competitive with elite schools. UVA has relationships with other regional universities, making collaboration attractive. The University is heading in a more progressive direction and allocating resources to causes like diversity, community engagement, and alternative forms of scholarship. Governance is slowly becoming less a matter of an old boys network. Location is beautiful and has easy access to east coast or rural Appalachia. Students are typically high achievers and there is a strong sense of student ownership over the school.
cons:
Macro: entitlement, historic racism that still remains strong, strong alumni can be problematic for reform, intellectually rather conservative, metrics for students and faculty often dominate over wisdom or long term strategy.
Micro: Your experience as a non-tenure track faculty member can be amazing (cf. languages, education, data science, and communication departments) or potentially terrible (engineering, global studies, CS); it all depends on leadership and bureaucracy at the time.

review_title: Years of a great work environment, last few years were not so good.
pros: Overall, many good people are a part of the UVA Health System. Some bad apples, as any location, but for the most part, I enjoyed my 16+ years. The higher-level administration were always receptive and just seemed like regular people. I never felt intimidated.
cons: The immediate department manager was not very good in my opinion. Didn't have good people skills. Let his personal opinions about employees affect how he dealt with them and how he evaluated them. Seem to not always understand the job of the staff that was managed or how to accept constructive advice based on our experiences. The last few years there were very disappointing and uncomfortable. job_title: Ph D Student in Charlottesville, VA
pros: There are some great people at UVA. Everyone is friendly, the teachers care about their students, and a lot of impactful research gets done.
cons: Being successful as a Ph.D. student is heavily dependent on your advisor, and my advisor isn't helpful. Her approach is too hands-off for me, and I constantly felt like I needed more attention and more guidance than I was given. Also, as is common for Ph.D. students, the stipend is very little money compared to what someone in my field could make in a real job. Finally, UVA's entire parking and transportation system is awful. I could drive to my building from my apartment in about 20 minutes, but I wasn't allowed to park in any of the lots near my building despite there being room. Instead, I was required to park far away and take a bus, which increased my commute time to 45 minutes to an hour depending on bus congestion.

review_title: Great for young adults, and that's it.
pros: This position allows you to teach and empower a team of part time managers and sales associates to meet and exceed sales numbers. You'll travel 3-4 times a year for local and national workshops to meet your other districts while learning new company tools and programs. You'll have chances to meet a lot of the vendors the company carries and even some higher level celebrities a couple times out of the year. The company is big on culture.
cons: The pay does not reflect you work you have to put into your position. It's a great pay coming out of high school or early 20's, but the fact that you can make the same amount of money delivering food as a store manager should say something. They're a cheap company that has liberal views but is quite obviously very conservative when it comes to money. Your store has a limited amount of payroll, enough to have 1 or maybe 2 people on the sales floor. Things WILL get stolen and it WILL be your fault. If you enjoy putting in more work each year for a less than a dollar raise, this is the position for you.

review_title: There is an unbreakable glass ceiling at UVA.
pros: The School of Medicine is a very small part of the largest employer in Charlottesville, which is UVA. There are many perks to working at UVA, ie. it is one of the top hospitals in the country, has good educational benefits, has better health benefits than most employers,  it is centrally located within the city and is located on the city bus route. The grounds of the university are a good respite from a hectic day at work with 10 beautiful gardens just a few minutes walk from the medical center.
cons: Staff is not appropriately rewarded or recognized for their accomplishments. Monetary rewards are reserved for Faculty, which are not necessarily the ones doing the work that is being rewarded. Some supervisors go to great lengths to ensure "staff knows their proper place" in an effort to suppress career aspirations. Aspiring employees are often viewed as a threat instead of an asset and are most definitely not utilized to their full potential. Disrespect runs rampant through our small office creating the potential (most days) for a strained and hostile working environment.

pros: The environment and culture are very fast paced. Working as an engineering intern, you are given a project and spend the summer attempting to complete it.  You should be able to consult a manager or graduate student if help is needed.  The environment is pretty relaxed and the bar scene is a lot less crowded.  The weather is generally nice and there is a lot to do in the surrounding areas.  Heading to DC, Lake Anna, Humpback Rock, and other places is something to do on the weekends if the bar scene is overplayed.  Intern with UVa if you want to network for grad school too.
cons:
Can be too many distractions. The projects can sometimes be frustrating and hard to complete.  There aren't a lot of interns working with you, so you'll either be alone or with another co-worker.  Sometimes the advisor is too busy and can be away from helping you through the project.  
Living in Charlottesville is VERY expensive, but this can be relieved by subletting into apartments or houses.  Check craigslist.org or hoohasit.com or ask around from friends for open spots.  UVa studnets must hold a year long lease and not everyone does summer school or stays in town during the summer months.

review_title: Great area and environment, pay could be much better
pros:
- Wonderful place to live
- Benefits package is good for the area
- Work life balance is encouraged and management is flexible for the most part
- Jobs here are generally stable as a State institution.  People rarely get laid off and many people retire here after many years of service.
cons:
- Communication from Human Resources and their organization is terrible.
- Education benefits are nice, but barely pay for anything these days with tuition rates.
- Promotion can be hard within departments, which forces you to move on after time
- Pay here is not nearly enough in comparison to other companies, even other State institutions.  Economy vastly affects raises (none in the last three years) and bonuses.

review_title: NOT A JOB HOPPER?    APPLY TO DARDEN!
pros: The Darden Business School and the University of Virginia offers a good work/life balance, flexibility in hours, the Dean is eager to listen to 'anyone' within the community.   All in all, Darden is like one big family and it makes it a pleasure to come to work each day.     There is rarely a day that I 'dread' coming to work and I don't believe most people can say that about their employer.
cons: Some downsides would be the exorbitant amount we have to pay to park at the school.   However, other UVA employees typically have to park away from their building and then walk or catch a shuttle.   At least at Darden, our car is always handy for when errands need to be run, etc.   I honestly cannot think of any other downsides.

review_title: A great opportunity in terms of experience gained and the privilege of working in such an historically significant venue
pros:
Diverse community, lots of opportunity to gain experience and move into other positions, training opportunities, good benefits, great local community and culture.

Employees have fast access to health care when needed through Employee Connection and Employee Health programs. 

$2,000 per year employee education allowance.
cons:
Parking issues - cost, location, inconvenience, time needed to get to/from work location to parking areas. Not enough buses serving hospital locations.

LEAD@UVA employee evaluation system is very annoying, not user friendly, and time consuming. A real pain to deal with this for annual and interim evaluations - and a deal breaker for me going forward. The concept of employee evaluations is good, but this system is infuriating.

pros: The sense of community among graduate students at the University is really phenomenal. I've interacted with a huge number of students in my time there, and the general vibe is that this is a great place to be a graduate student. If you're covered as a teaching or research assistant, the pay is reasonable and the healthcare benefits are really quite good. There is also a tremendous support infrastructure.
cons: Grad students don't get dental benefits covered. With the low salary, I really think this is mandatory. Admitted, it is typical, but that doesn't make it right. Also, there is quite a bit of bureaucracy to deal with in all aspects of the work.

review_title: Grad Student Experience in UVA's Engineering School
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: UVA's engineering graduate school experience is a good one. It is a small community that knows each other fairly well. The small size making getting help and sharing ideas very easy. There is not much hierarchy and the faculty and staff are usually friendly.
cons: The mentors are professors who can vary tremendously depending on who you work under. Some professors are great bosses and encourage independent thinking. They are more than happy to give credit to their students and it works well for your overall growth. My experience was exactly that. However, some professors are known to be miserly when it comes to spending money. They also like to use their students as just a pair of hands to get more papers out. The other big con of this job would obviously be the salary. However that is true for most grad schools and you just have to suck it up till you graduate.

review_title: SEAS graduate student: mix of old/new facilities, great location
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Charlottesville, VA
pros:
Graduate students have access to excellent University supercomputing resources. There are several libraries/study spaces with almost any book or journal you would need. The rest can be obtained easily through inter-library loans. Housing is affordable once you get a bit further from grounds.

Charlottesville is a great town to live in; it is relatively small but there is a lot to do whatever your interests. UVA has several very good athletic programs; non-football or basketball events are fun and affordable. There are a lot of great places to eat: in terms of both quality and affordability. Charlottesville also has its own airport which can be useful, though flights are often canceled at it may be better to fly out of Richmond or Dulles.
cons: Depending on the department, the facilities can either be very nice or very dated.  Within a given department, the course selection can sometimes be limited. The school isn't too close to a major metropolitan area, which makes traveling to conferences more difficult.

pros: Working as a research assistant is great because you can walk around the department and meet other researchers, see other projects, and learn about what is happening in your field of interest. A good part-time job during school/summer to help further career/resume and also pay the rent.
cons: Salary is $10-12 and it is unlikely you'll receive a raise. Obviously no benefits as a part-time worker and it is hard to get approved to work full time.  I worked full time and ended up capping my hours, but since I didn't know I had a time cap, it threw a wrench into my budgeting as I was no longer able to make money with a month of summer left. Once the school year starts, you can only get paid for something like 10 hours a week.

review_title: Great University for a Graduate Teaching Assistant!
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Get to work with top rated faculty, teach smart hard-working students, and be supported by top notch administrative support. Experience the history of Thomas Jefferson's university, one of the oldest and best in the nation. Live in Charlottesville, consistently ranked as one of the happiest places in North America.
cons: The fellowship / salary for Graduate Teaching Assistants (GTAs) is too low. It has just been increased from $20,000 to $24,000 a year, which is a good start, but not enough. The full fellowship includes GTAs' tuition remission as graduate students, and health insurance, which puts the full fellowship at around $50,000 value, but the fact remains that with only $24,000 a year in actual funds, GTAs just manage to cover their basic room, board, and textbooks. There is no money left to save for the future, which is important, considering GTAs on average spend 6 years at the University.

review_title: Great benefits, fantastic students, constant intellectual stimulation
pros: The historic University of Virginia Grounds are the most beautiful place I have ever worked.  The students are extremely capable, and there are initiatives such as "BE SAFE" at the health sciences center that make this feel like a progressive institution that is trying to improve every day.
cons: While this is an institution that has traditionally put teaching first,  in the last few years, with change in Provost, there is a much bigger emphasis on the quest to obtain external funding and to conduct a LOT of high-powered research.  If you are a researcher at heart, you will find support here.  If you are not, you will be less successful and find that the work environment is very stressful.

review_title: There is value in attending a research based school. This is one of the best ones out there
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros:
Exposure to research - All students are required to have an advisor. Even Masters candidates are required to perform research that culminates in a thesis defense. During the course of this process, one gets to interact closely with professors.

Selective admits - Peer groups tend to have a big influence on one's experience in graduate school. Uva has no policies on diversity in background or ethnicity. It is a pure meritocracy. I see this as a positive towards admitting individuals who are professionally accomplished.

Funded admits are common. Even masters students are admitted with a TA. After a year into school, you are expected to work as an RA (by convincing a professor that you are worth his money). But the plus is that this track is the norm and not the exception.
cons:
Small department. So there is not a wide variety of courses on offer.
But courses are available in plenty online anyway

review_title: The University of Virginia is not a good place to work.
job_title: Human Resources Professional in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Working for the State of Virginia and having access to government benefits; however, this no longer applies for new employees. In recent years UVA has become a charter university. This means UVA conveniently now has one foot in the public sector and the other in the private. New employees do not have access to government benefits and are denied other fundamental employee rights.
cons: UVA is the largest employer in town by far and their very powerful. Locals go to work for UVA right out of high school/college and rarely leave; so, few promotional opportunities exist. Staff members are treated like second class citizens by the administration and by some faculty. Basically, they perform repetitive job duties that does not enhance their minds or careers. Since charter has gone into effect, things are even worse. Now employees work for a big corporation with few rights to protect them. Employees have 2 choices: agree with management and keep their mouth shut; or, quit or be fired.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: The materials science graduate program is healthy and the outlook for the department is good to fair. It may not be the flashiest program but the professors here make for a very inviting community. The majority of them are very competent scientists who enjoy better work life balance than you would expect at a top 10 school. You can get a great free graduate education and enjoy your life at the same time here at UVA. As far as producing respected research, it will be what you make it. If you are smart, the school has the tools and the money to allow you to flourish.
cons: The value of your time spent here will depend completely on you. You will not benefit from some of the advantages of  top 10 programs. It's possible to be very successful here but not guaranteed. You have to work to make yourself interesting through your research accomplishments.

pros: The soul of UVA is the support system and the character of the people. Not only do they hire excellent doctors who love to teach, care for their patients and are devoted to improving outcomes & systems, but they also have excellent custodial staff, chefs, groundskeepers who are the backbone of this place! The environment is cheerful (despite being a hospital) and there are always kind people smiling in the hall that remind me why I love working here.
cons: Like all modern health systems, expansion and modernization can somewhat take away from the kind, small-town feel. Overall, despite the changes to keep up with the times, UVA has maintained a very good outlook.

review_title: Great place to live and raise a family
pros: As a residence area, Charlottesville and the surrounding areas are probably one of the best in the country. The town is surrounded by so much green areas and the proximity of a national park makes living here worthwhile. Sports and health are a high priority of many community members. T. Jefferson chose a good place to build his university.
cons: Although the living conditions are quite nice, this is not the number 1 place for industrial and career development. The university faculty is world-known but if you're a scientist there are places with  better equipment.

pros: The university feels like a family.  It's a very supportive environment.  People really look out for each other.  It is intellectually curious and open.  The values of this university are strong, but they are also the values that tend to support collaborative learning.  The university's academic departments have  a surprising amount of mutual respect.  It is not uncommon for a phd student to take doctoral-level coursework in another department and (in general) the university is very supportive of it.  Also, the undergraduates tend to be smart and hard-working, which makes teaching and TA'ing much more rewarding.
cons: Charlottesville is a smaller community.  Not a small town, but not a city either.  That is a negative depending on a person's preferences.  It can also be a positive.  T

pros: Medical school has excellent core facilities for researchers and many resources for internal funding opportunities. Research community is collegial, collaborative and very hands-on (a big plus for grad students and post docs). Charlottesville is a wonderful town to live, work and raise a family in.  The benefits are absolutely top-notch, everything from FSA, HSA, 10 days of backup care when your kids are sick, medical that you can choose (high vs low premium) and as a hospital, top notch in-network docs.
cons: It is very difficult to get promoted (especially if you are non-tenure). The process is long and convoluted, requiring the appointee to actually re-apply for their position with a different title and salary. The process can take months and months of wrangling with HR and is a huge reason why retention of talent is pretty poor.

review_title: A better than average place to be a postdoc
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Wonderful climate, affordable cost of living -- Charlottesville's a great college town. Staff in general are quite friendly and helpful (the cliche about southern hospitality has some basis in reality, I think.)
cons: All the usual downsides of being a postdoc apply, chief among them the fact that it's a temp job at best and you'll find yourself moving across the country in another two years, and that picking the wrong research project or lab group to join can torpedo your career before it really even starts. Also, it's ridiculously hard to get to DC.

pros: Job security, access to strong educational and other resources a good school offers.
cons: The school's general emphasis is not on science, the area I worked in, resulting in some lack of support and slightly below average morale amongst researchers.

review_title: A great institution with many benefits
pros: UVa boasts many benefits for its staff. You are given a great health care package through it's medical school, the benefits matching is superb, you are given many vacation days from the onset, and the retirement matching is superb. The town is a great place to live in and the ability to attend events at University-partnered venues at a discount makes every day exciting!
cons: One of the challenges of living in Charlottesville is learning to deal with the undergraduate culture. It is a smallish college town so sometimes it feels like you are living in a college bubble. In addition, it may be difficult to be promoted as many of the staff have been working their for a long time.

review_title: Overall happy with opportunities and education offered
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros:
Well known recognizable school name, beautiful campus, rich long history.
Great opportunities to do important research in my department (Physics) in world-leading projects.
Some very good professors/researchers.
Lots of resources offered by the University.
Physics Department is often very supportive of students.
cons:
Not one of the absolute very best schools, better reserach opportunities elsewhere - but still very good.
Also I've noticed that professors and grad students are not as "close" as in other schools. I mean, I've certainly had beers with my advisor and we have had very open conversations. But the department as a whole could do better in the professors-students interaction. I certainly don't think it's a bad atmosphere though.
Building of Physics Department feels a little old.

review_title: PhD Student at University of Virginia, a caring environment for driven people!
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: First, UVA is an excellent school and the program for which I work BIMS (M.I.C.) is offers a competitive environment in which I can openly share ideas and get feedback about my projects. The University as a whole values collaboration and my mentor instills a sense of wonder about the world around me. It's such a great learning environment. The compensation is competitive with other graduate school biomedical science program stipends as well.
cons: It is almost expected that students continue on the "academia" route for science as opposed to industry, government or other consulting type positions.

review_title: Nothing too special about working here.
pros: Pay was decent, but not anything extraordinary. Staff are generally very intelligent people. Grounds are beautiful and there's great things within walking distance.
cons: Have to pay for parking at one of the University's garages. Have to ride a bus to and from your office to get to your car. Buses are often packed and drive right past people waiting to go home, causing them to wait another 15 minutes or walk a mile. HR is not responsive to issues brought up by employees about their managers. There's a huge pay difference between the faculty and the staff, faculty spending waste is out of control. There's not much schedule flexibility when you're an admin assistant, you must be there to answer the phone no matter what.

review_title: An institution amid significant cultural struggle
pros: No question that this is a very storied, wonderful University. But also no question that the University is way behind from an operations standpoint, and in order to stay competitive/relevant must now catch up after many years of indifference/entrenchment/being too impressed with itself. The University additionally appears to be starting to think and act strategically, though senior management largely leaves this work to individuals they recruit from outside the University (or consultants).  A lot of opportunity but also difficulty awaits any change agent.
cons: UVA's (continuing) perplexing response to the march of the white supremacists last summer; questionable institutional structure and infrastructure. Lots of groupthink so as to keep everyone feeling comfortable and not having to work too hard.

pros: Pay was decent, and hours are flexible. Few professors follow require strict deadlines. Tutoring center is located in a new, nice, quiet space in Gilmer Hall.
cons: Tutoring can be a bit of a chore, when you realize that the majority of your students will want you to do their homework for them. Some students will come week after week seeking help while obviously not putting in any work themselves to improve, since they will keep asking the same questions as the last week.

pros: Strong, reputable academic environment provides a backdrop to gain valuable experience working with a variety of people at many levels
cons: Being an older institution that prides itself on having many ties to DC, there is a distinct hierarchy in how people interact with one another. Compared to other institutions I’ve worked since, work atmosphere at UVA was somewhat cold, lacking in friendly conversation and interactions, as I was only an assistant and not someone more important.

pros: scientific environment and collaboration at medical center.  Great resources and environment to to reasearch.  Top notch research institute.  very competitive and expected to be very competitive.
cons: Parking sucks!!! It adds at least two extra hours to your day. Buses are never on time.  Kept in post-doc position too long.  worked too hard expected to work eighty plus hours diffucult to balance family and personal life with work.  Day care options are non existant to none.  There is a two plus year wait list for UVa day care.  Can be diffucult to obtain faculty position here unless you have an "in".

review_title: Do NOT work here, almost no HR services and culture that tolerates abuse of non-faculty staff
pros: UVA is beautiful.  Great for resume building.  Charlottesville is a nice small town to live in.
cons: Darden is so removed from the rest of UVA that it is a world on itself and wants to stay that way.  Connection between UVA and Darden is neutral to hostile at times.  Dean is weak and will protect faculty but not staff.  Bullying behavior of management is tolerated. HR is a joke and do very little to protect employees.  I saw several examples where bonuses and benefits were denied employees.  There are lawsuits waiting to happen here.  So sexist.

review_title: I loved the atmosphere of the campus and Charlottesville.  I would love to work for UVA again and live in the area.
job_title: Director of Strategy in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Lovely workplace on campus, positive energy from students, strong values system and cherished historical legacy, great infrastructure, competitive salaries, good lifestyle and work/ life balance.  I really liked the support staff who I found to be competent, genteel and good humored - very Virginian!
cons: As with many universities there are Internal politics, hidden agendas and some passive/ aggressive behavior by the faculty.  I found the administrative leaders were often struggling to create and maintain alignment with the faculty on their vision and goals for the future.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: You get health care and have the option to pay for dental insurance.  The thesis and dissertation guidelines are not very strict.   The campus is beautiful and Charlottesville is a nice place to live as a student.
cons: Crappy dental plan for graduate students.  Parking around campus can be problematic.  After you finish taking classes, you no longer get free admission to football games.  Deadlines for completed theses and dissertations change nonsensically from year to year.  By the nature of graduate school, the typical student will probably not have much time to enjoy the beautiful campus.  There are no decent local movie theaters.

review_title: I served as the Assistant Marine Officer Instructor during my active duty service in the USMC.
job_title: Assistant Marine Officer Instructor in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Charlottesville is a great place to live in work.  Surrounded by the Blue Ridge mountains its a beautiful campus.  A rich tradition that goes back to 1819 when UVA was founded by our former President Thomas Jefferson.  The University also offers a wide variety of course-work and majors.
cons: Not a lot of negitive to report about working at UVA.  I guess the one downfall about Charlottesville is it's high cost of living.

review_title: Great school and a great place to work
pros: Good health benefits, collegiate working environment, smart co-workers, good network infrastructure & bandwidth, one free course each semester, free microsoft apps via ELMS, library subscription to O'Reilly technical books.
cons: Hard to find documentation about some topics related to job, large collection of documents on UVa web with many out of date or contradictory, many great things out there that don't get maintained, frequent thrashing of hardware and software systems by UVa IT dept (ITS), too much reliance on shoddy Microsoft software by ITS.

pros: You can set your own hours, unless an experiment is running.  There are many international students who provide interesting views on the world and expand your horizons.  The university as a whole is a nice place to be.
cons: The pay is lousy, and many faculty can't even come up with enough to keep their students from having to TA.  Most faculty, particularly the ones in charge, treat graduate students like children.  The technical work is tedious, and this is exacerbated by the fact that in the big picture, it's all irrelevant.

pros: They sincerely care about education and provide great tuition assistance. The best part about working here has been the management. Eileen and Terry are approachable and open to employees ideas concerning patient care and scheduling. Since starting here I have found that the culture has always been about building excellent nurses and better outcomes for patients. Even as a new hire they look for ways to include you in the decision making processes of the unit. Your thoughts and input matter.
cons: Staffing can be thin at times but has gotten better. Management is addressing this by hiring quality staff that can be retained along with opening a few traveler positions.

review_title: Good place for a part-time job for students!
job_title: Career Resource Specialist in Charlottesville, VA
pros: I worked as a career resource assistant for the university career center and really enjoyed my time. My scheduling was extremely flexible with classes, and if I had an emergency my manager was also very understanding if I had to take off for any reason. Also had enough flexibility on the job that I could get my work done from my classes while being at the front desk.
cons: Pay isn't great, but it's good for a first-time job and/or if you want to make extra money. You don't really get to work on academic breaks and/or if class gets cancelled, but may have the option to do so if you ask.

review_title: A good, stable place to work but has its limitations.
pros: There is a great atmosphere.  Other employees are friendly and fun to work with.  It is a stable employer, because you don't have to worry about it going out of business.
cons: It is still an old-fashioned place to work in many ways.  Jobs and promotions are given based on who you know as much as on skills and accomplishments.  You won't grow rich working here unless you are in upper management.

job_title: Post Doctoral Research Associate in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Great for personal growth, in education, presentation mannerisms, and thought processes. Fantastic region to live in, plenty of things to do. Training opportunities are a plenty. I personally am extremely happy about my choice in boss (PI), and feel that I've been given many chances to go to conferences, national labs, and training sessions in many different regions.
cons: Cons more due to the nature of research itself, which is a fickle beast. Work-life balance is pretty good, except around grant renewal / writing time, when things become super hectic. I can't complain much about the salary of a graduate student, as health care and education costs are covered.

review_title: Very little room for advancement in this Good Ole' Boys network
pros: Relatively large amounts of time off; flexibility in work schedule; observe university, state & some federal holidays
cons: Low pay relative to other universities of a comparable size; extremely high cost of living in Charlottesville and surrounding regions due to the high pay of professors, MDs and other professionals that choose to live in this region; great difficulty in executing your assigned tasks due to a systemic apathy of university employees; most positions are dead-ends w/ little room for advancement; very few cash bonuses

review_title: For staff employees, relatively secure employment, but not very satisfying work.
pros: Beautiful grounds and some good coffee shops
cons: Not much room for growth and no raises. Extremely tedious evaluation process (2x per year with interim and annual evals), but few, if any, rewards for hard workers. The reward for lifers who sit in a chair and bully people away from them to avoid having to work are the same as for hard workers.

pros: I have worked for UVA (Curry School of Education) on several different field research projects and some of my experiences have been incredible - communicative supervisors who are willing to listen to feedback and very prompt and constructive in their help and feedback.
cons: The bummer is if the project manager on your assignment isn't great, it really affects your day-to-day job experience. In particular, I've experienced trouble with a supervisor who is not very communicative (often sending assignments at the last minute) and not receptive to feedback from data collectors in the field

review_title: I worked for a large department, handling their hiring and other HR tasks. Overall, a nice place to work.
job_title: Human Resources Manager  in Charlottesville, VA
pros: The opportunity to work with great people at a prestigious University.
cons: They have some long-standing issues with entrentched leaders and bad behavior. Like any big institution, they like to keep these things quiet. Those with money and power (like researchers wo bring in big grant money) can do as they please with no regard to rules. The University does not like people who protest or try to change things.

job_title: Study Abroad Advisor in Charlottesville, VA
pros: The director to whom I reported was wonderful.   She allowed her staff freedom and independence while providing support when needed.  The work was varied enough to stay interesting, and professional development opportunities were abundant.
cons: There was nowhere to grow and stay within the office.  You couldn't gain management experience or take on job responsibilities that would even lead to a raise in salary.  There was also a considerable differential between international student advisor pay and study abroad advisor pay.  It created a division in the office that was not healthy.

review_title: Average compensation, average management, great Grounds and facilities, nice town.
pros: Eateries around town, recreational facilities, historic Lawn and surrounding architecture, educational benefits / compensation, proximity to Richmond Virginia and Washington, DC.
cons: Outside of the teaching faculty there is a lot of turnover for top talent because there is a lack of lateral and upward promotion - especially in bad economic conditions.

pros: easy part time job during the school year, pay is decent and all i do is sit there and do homework and ocassionally check things out to people. overall its pretty good. fits in well with class schedule, and they are very understanding when you need to post a sub. also you always get university breaks off and dont have to fulfill your hours during exam times. in general i do not mind working here but sometimes its annoying.
cons: not the best hours, some times i have worked here til two am, this semester the latest i have to work is til midnight.

pros: Great benefits, plenty of smart people, work environment can be fun with all of the events that are constantly going on.  Being a part of the university community is also a huge perk, especially since it comes without most of the red tape that goes along with official University jobs.
cons: Little opportunity for advancement (such is often the case with smaller organizations).  Although the Alumni Association has grown a bit over the years, there is only so much potential for growth.

pros: Reliable pay, good job security, very generous and flexible leave/vacation policy, progressive and tolerant work environment, little to know unpaid overtime for staff.
cons: Promotion usually requires either getting a new position created for you, or moving from department to department. The relationship between faculty and staff will depend heavily on your organizational culture. Ultimately, the university wants to squeeze more productivity from fewer staff (just like most private companies), while at the same time, there is perhaps too much leeway for unproductive employees at the expense of a hardworking few.

pros:
Surrounded by beautiful central Virginia
Added some actually personally enriching courses to personal enrichment courses covered by benefits; overall, benefits are not bad
Nice infrastructure
Many nice students and co-workers.
Just love "no pets or undergrads" in apartment ads
cons:
Exercise caution when walking on-campus when students move between lectures: their attention to people around are no better than that of 5-yr olds, but they bump into you much stronger
If using flexible spending account, watch for their March or April deadline to request reimbursement, otherwise your money will be eagerly and legally stolen (might sound like an oxymoron, but I apply "stolen" in both moral and ethical sense here)

review_title: A good program to its grad students
pros: The environment for grad students at UVa is supportive, encouraging, and positive.  Many resources available, lots of mentors and systems in place to help out. I am parting ways with academia but am aware that compared to many universities, UVa pays grad students fairly, does not overwork them, and treats them like human beings.
cons: Academia itself is a toxic nightmare with serious baked-in issues that need to be addressed; too many people are being trained for such an overall exploitative and oversaturated job market.  None of this is UVa's fault but it exists within that system.

review_title: Easy job but can be a drag
pros:
-Attendants are all university students so your shifts are great depending on who you work with
-They like to organize social events for the attendants
-Free towels!
cons:
-Shifts can be a drag.  Especially if there is no one in the gym
-Attendant meetings are boring.  The managers try to force those "leadership development" principles, but it all ends up being cheesy and unhelpful.

review_title: The good, The bad, and The ugly
pros: The benefits here with the university are outstanding.  The vacation time is advanced to you at the beginning of the year and overall they at least present a caring appearance for the employees.
cons: The parking here is pathetic, there is an us vs them concept at times between the academic and health sides as well as within three primary employers on the health side.  It can be confusing and confrontational at times.  Advancement is not popular.

review_title: Amazing place once hired, but you'll need a second income, and don't plan on any merit raises, promotions, or bonuses
pros:
- There are a huge variety of organizations at UVA - ergo, a huge variety of jobs. And, because it's a state organization, it is extremely rare for anyone to get laid off. So, job security is a major plus.
- There is tremendous respect for public service, and community involvement. So, if you are passionate about this (as opposed to, say, doing your job), there is an amazingly supportive culture
- A wide variety of activities, events, concerts, etc. The place is world-class happening.
- The connection to this country's founding fathers (particularly Jefferson and Monroe) is impressive and palpable. History is everywhere.
- The grounds (campus) is drop dead gorgeous - as is the fall and spring weather. The grounds/facilities dept is amazing, trees, gardens, grass are, to put it mildly, fantastic.
- The new (2007) Event venue (John Paul Jones Arena) and its event program is world class.
- The library system is unbelievable. The underground special collections library has to be seen to be believed...
- The IT dept works incredibly hard to provide open, free access to both the Internet, and an enormous variety of hardware and software.
- The is tremendous respect for free speech and expression.
- Everyone seems to be beautiful, so who needs the annual SI swimsuit edition!
cons:
- Because of the above (especially the job security), many people stay on in the same job for 20-40 years. As a result, very little chance for advancement or real recognition. Salaries are stagnant, and the only way to move up is to jump into new jobs in another department.
- Although there are a huge variety of activities, they all seem to cost a lot of money (how about a play for $34), and there are no staff discounts. Students get in free, staff pay full freight.
- Summer weather is HOT and HUMID!
- Yes, there is a winter, which can be long and dreary.
- Although UVA is not in a major metro area, cost of living is quite high. 
- The place is actually run by thousands of committees! (and thus, millions of meetings ;-)

review_title: A great work environment, and a great town to live in.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: You'll never run out of opportunities at UVA.  Being surrounded by some of the smartest students and most accomplished professors in the country doesn't hurt either.   Charlottesville is a great place to live, and it offers a respectable cultural and historical scene as well as a night life above what you'd expect from a town its size.
cons: The combination of effects from internal and state government politics can get very close to home.  While some departments are outstanding, many others don't live up to the reputation of the university.

review_title: Great People and Great Place to Work
pros: I worked with wonderful and Intelligent People. Very professional and goal oriented. One of the best Management that I have ever seen in an organization. Like seriously, I absolutely adored and respected my Boss and the people I worked with at UVA. Hopefully, I get to work at UVA again someday. Great place, great people and a lot of real impactful work and research.
cons: No Cons that I saw or noticed. Absolutely none.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: The campus is pretty, as is surrounding Albemarle County.  Charlottesville is a small city, but there is a good variety of bars and restaurants plus decent entertainment, including the yearly Virginia film festival.  Strong running scene.  In SEAS, there is a social organization that puts good effort into organizing regular barbecues for graduate students.
cons: The Board of Visitors debacle, but nothing else particular to UVa that one wouldn't find at another university or in the Piled Higher and Deeper comic strip.

review_title: Great place to be a grad student, but lack of transparency is frustrating
pros: Strong undergraduate students, excellent faculty
cons: Graduate students often remain left in the dark (and are rarely consulted) about decisions that affect their lives. Training for teaching is spotty at best. The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences still hasn't hired a career development person for the graduate students.

pros: This is my second stint at UVA and having worked in a 3-story brick building in the suburbs of a large city, I am again in awe of this beautiful place. It is a privilege to be here and I am very proud of UVA. Everyday I meet people from all over the world, and even though I am an employee I know my experience here has also been an education - so I consider myself a student as well. I am fortunate to be working for someone I admire and respect immensely - and whom I support with great enthusiasm. It makes a huge difference in my life. Not everyone will have that - at UVA or anywhere else, but this remains one amazing place to be in this world. It can be difficult to get in the door, but once you do the opportunities are extensive. The right attitude makes a difference, and for those with a great work ethic, UVA can put you on the path to a very nice future.
cons: Parking will always be an issue, as well as bus transportation to and from parking areas. Waiting 10-15+ minutes for a bus and having it arrive with the "Bus Full" sign on is frustrating as heck. I resent the time I waste waiting for a bus every morning and afternoon. I walk when I can, but depending on what I have to carry and/or the weather, I can't always walk. Seeing one bus after another pass with the "Not in Service" light on only makes it more frustrating. I don't think anyone who schedules buses or presides over the budget for them has any idea what it's like to wait for "Bus Full" and "Not in Service" buses to pass day after day, in the dark, in freezing cold, rain, or hot and humid weather. Adding extra green route buses in the morning and afternoons so people don't have to be crammed in like sardines would make for much happier faces coming in and out of the buildings everyday. I'd rather get back the time I waste at the bus stop than have a raise - but getting both would be fantastic.

pros: The University of Virginia is a great place to work as a student employee.  There are many opportunities for students to learn and grow--especially in areas of human resources and development.
cons: Sometimes, it is difficult to implement new and improved policies to senior officials because of the traditions that the school has had in place for many years.  It is okay to mix it up!

review_title: Some genuinely great people here, but some awful, myopic administrators overseeing everything
pros: The university is strong in most programs.  Charlottesville is relatively safe for a college town.
cons:
The administration has changed key policies that affect graduate students, e.g. how long students have to complete there PhD and immediately applied those policies to existing students.  So when I arrived here, for example, I assumed that certain deadlines were flexible and that I would have 6 years to graduate.  Half way through my time here, a new administrator made all the deadlines set in stone and announced that there would no longer be 6th year funding.  I was working under a different set of assumptions, so I was not adequately prepared for the sudden changes.  The school also keeps raising graduate student pay due to inflation and competition for graduate students, while keeping the pay of existing students constant.  There was a point where students doing the exact same job could making anywhere from 16-24k a year.  This is the difference between barely scraping by in Charlottesville and being able to set aside money for the future.  I've also heard that our current dean sees little value in the social sciences and frequently makes decisions accordingly.

Besides the high level administration being absolutely awful, whether or not your individual experience with your academic advisor is good will vary wildly.  Some professors are naturally good mentors, teachers, and supporters.  Others, are incompetent at one or more of these things.  The university provides little training for those that fail at their role in mentoring PhDs.

Also, assume that there will be few jobs and post-docs available for you in academia when you graduate and that the university will do next to nothing to prepare you for a job outside of academia.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Charlottesville is a beautiful town, lots of friendly people.  Depending on the department, professors can be very friendly, but most are swamped with their own research.
cons: Professors vary widely in their ability to interact with human beings.  Salaries for graduate students are meager.  Not much in the way of mentorship (depends on department).

pros: The opportunity to work with some of the greatest students and academicians in the country.  A theoretically strong system of advancement and merit pay.
cons: The University is loosing its missing as a major research university.  The current Board of Visitors, and legislative influence is turning it in to a trade school.  Too much change at the top without clear direction.

pros: The University of Virginia is a great place to work. The culture, traditions and values are the best I've ever experienced. The staff and employees are treated well by their supervisors and there is a relaxed feel.
cons: Being stuck at part-time is disheartening. It seems that every position starts part-time and those who pay their dues can advance to full-time with benefits. Many good talents are lost because of more lucrative offers.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Hi visibility for employers.  The prestige associated with this institution and its faculty provides excellent networking opportunities for the next career step.
cons: MAE is not extremely well respected in the community.  However, certain researchers are leading the charge in their fields and stand out from the rest at UVA.

pros: It was nice working full-time at my university over the summer. UVA Conference Services offers free housing for all assistants and the workload is manageable.
cons: During events such as graduation or the alumni reunions the workload can get overwhelming from time to time, especially if an assistant is on call from 8 pm to 8 am it can get tough.

pros: Great way to really learn material that you've "learned" before. Also a great way to build relationships with professors that you might ask for a recommendation later.
cons: As an undergraduate TA, you don't really get many hours and the pay isn't the best

job_title: Computer Systems Engineer in Charlottesville, VA
pros:
you will never be transferred.

They are committed to zero layoffs
cons:
you will be managed by a tenured professor who has no management skills and 
possibly no people skills.  Pay scales are terrible.  If you are at the bottom (as an IT worker or programmer) the prof or dean who runs your unit will be making twice what you make.

We have had two salary freezes in the last ten years for a total of 4.5 years without a raise.

We cannot trust management to do the right thing.

job_title: Senior Network Engineer in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Good stable work environment, Charlottesville is a fantastic city with little traffic and epicureans dilemma with all the great restaurants in town. Great active town.
cons: Once you get a position here it is hard to move up and promotions are rarely heard of. Learn how to negotiate before coming here and get the highest salary you can start with, it won't change for years......

pros: Beautiful campus in a very nice city. Good health insurance and benefits. If you are hired, you have very good job security.
cons: Low salaries. Very little employee recognition for a job well done. Not enough resources for information technologies and very few advancement opportunities. Parking and transportation are very difficult. Insular and provincial culture that makes it hard for those not from the local area to feel like they fit in.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: beautiful campus, great area, lots to do in Charlottesville. I had a good experience with my advisor but this can be subjective based on your personal relationship and the quality of the faculty in your department.
cons: One of the biggest cons for me is that it's far from home.  I also sometimes struggled to get the help I needed when my work hit a roadblock.

pros: There are a lot of resources available to students and staff. It has been an experience where you learn a lot on the job, but there are always people there to help you.
cons: There are a lot of politics involved with working at UVA. Also people that are higher up (administration, etc.) seen to have an entitled air about them.

pros: Totally depends on your group.  People are pleasant for the most part. The environment is good.  The sports center is fantastic.  The football games are nice. Good for people early in their careers or who want to start a family here.
cons: Be mindful of administration.  Salary is modest and not much scope for growth unless you are a high flying academic.  But most high flyers leave the place sooner or later.

pros: Great atmosphere and environment.  The people are all very nice and easy to get along with.  Charlottesville is a beautiful town and a very fun place to live.
cons: Hard to stand out on the job, and its easy to get lost in the shuffle rather than moving up in the ranks.  Concerns were sometimes swept under the rug and were not communicated to the right personnel.

pros: Working on a college campus is great.  There are a lot of great restaurants within walking distance.  Charlottesville is a great town.  Good food, local wineries, and farmers markets.
cons: I thought the research focus of the department was somewhat limited.  There is a lot of research being done in Software Engineering and Sensor Networks.

review_title: Met great researchers, experiences vary widely.
pros: Some of the research can be very engaging and the regular meetings keep you focused on making progress. We are encouraged to give our input and contribute to the final project.
cons: Though encouraged to give feedback, often it seemed that feedback was ill understood or not listened to. Many times the research outcome was a permutation of earlier research efforts leaving one thinking that more could have been done.

review_title: Run away as fast as you can
pros: Work-life balance is life focused. Great food and wine, if you have the money for it. Easy commute with great bus system.
cons: Terrible place for research. Lazy researchers work 10-5 M-F. Idea theft. Unwillingness to collaborate. Filled with researchers that had money in the 90s, but everyone had money in the 90s. Now, most labs don't have money. Professors constantly complain about funding and academic management. Quality of research is below par. A waste of tax payer money.

pros: This is a great place to work. I worked in the academic side, and the management's attitude towards the research staff is very good. Of course, it all depends on the department. The benefits are awesome, full medical, dental, pension, etc.
cons:
If you are working in research, there is no way to move up in within the university. (Unless you are a professor.) All others need to get a job somewhere else if they want a promotion.
Parking is very expensive and not guaranteed.

pros:
*flexiblity
*good job for students to undertake in their free time
*good training opportunities
*work as much as you want
cons:
*Low pay
*Have to deal with unruly passengers more frequently than not
*Driving can be a little boring

job_title: Digitization Service Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: You will have the chance to touch tons of rare materials which alway make the tedious scanning process funny. Staffs are very friendly, and the working environment is fairly fantastic.
cons: You have to work at least 10 hours a week as a student, which is a very large amount of time. Also, you cannot do anything else than working in the office because personal staffs are prohibited. Even though the hour salaries are higher than other on campus jobs, it is a very heavy workload.

review_title: Great university; outstanding professors; low pay
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: U.Va. is an outstanding university with brilliant students. The university itself has seemingly limitless resources, and can easily secure you funding. It's located in Charlottesville, a lovely town with lots of things to do.
cons: The graduate student stipend is low compared to other, similar programs, and you will never receive a raise. No matter if you are teaching one class or three- you will always be paid the same.

pros: Benefits package was fabulous and my direct teammates  were wonderful people. I was also given the opportunity to develop a new school without much experience.
cons: I worked in a department that had an authoritarian boss.  Morale was low due to an inept transition plan, when moving to a cost recovery model coupled with a  30% increase in rates.

pros: I work with a very Professional Team of people. Everyone is very driven and goal oriented. All my colleagues and people I have interacted with in the organization are very knowledgeable. Everyone is highly skilled in their work. I am excited to go to office every morning for work.
cons: No cons so far whatsoever.

pros:
Access to UVa. 

Convenient in terms of location and the wide variety of things to do in the area.

Fairly flexible schedule.

Keeps your knowledge of the material sharp.
cons:
Unless you're looking to stay in academia, the title doesn't carry too much weight and there aren't any immediate advancement opportunities without further education.

The pay is hourly and graduated with level of education, not by merit.

pros: The professors are very nice and helpful. The resources in University of Virginia are rich. The professors encourage you to think creatively.
cons: The salary in my department is relatively lower than other departments in the University of Virginia.   As a student, sometimes I feel hard to balance my study and work.

pros: Access to university events, consistent hours, and flexible work for a university student who is taking a full time course load. Working on a college campus provides a fun and exciting atmosphere.
cons: Level of employee talent is not equivalent to the private sector. Employees take advantage of   university system, as it is almost impossible to get let go.

review_title: UVA is great for grad school
pros: Charlottesville is an awesome city to live in, especially during graduate school. The health system has excellent opportunities to extend research to the clinic.
cons: The nearest H&M is in Richmond, which is an at least an hour away. The other option is DC which is a 2 to 2.5 hour drive.

pros: My job allows me to wear many hats, is largely self managed, and allows me to stretch in grow in new ways all the time.
cons: Being self managed can be hard when direction or next steps are not obvious. In addition, not receiving immediate feedback on work can lead to some level of anxiety.

pros: beautiful campus, great access to resources, talented and smart coworkers and senior researchers, very collaborative environment, great work life balance and flexible hours, although at times (especially in the basic science) long shifts are necessary
cons: As with all public academic institutions, research funding is often an issue. It might be hard to switch between labs in the middle of the program, if something between you and your advisor doesn't click, or your interest change.

review_title: I am a graduate student in the microbiology, immunology and cancer biology department.
pros: As a graduate student, this is a great place to do a PhD.  Top reasons in no particular order are 1) Quality of research/faculty 2) Abundance of things to do in Charlottesvile 3) great compensation for the cost of living.
cons: I cannot think of any cons to doing a PhD at the University of Virginia in the microbiology, immunology and cancer biology department.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros:
Good community relationship.  The Chemistry department takes an active stance in helping address concerns that come up throughout the graduate program.  

Excellent access to research instrumentation.

UVA offers a great deal of support from teaching help to career counseling.
cons:
Initial coursework offered little in subdisciplines.  This has been remedied in the past few years with the the addition of many young, new faculty hires.

Could use more hands-on training in order to make the many resources of UVA more accessible.

review_title: A great place to work in the basic sciences
pros: The place is well equipped and is a great local community. Working hard and playing/training hard is a local trend. There are plenty of interesting things to do for everyone and the people love good things.
cons: The university is in a small town. The town itself is great, but driving in town will only slow you down. The night life is not nonexistent, but it finding things to do is not always easy.

review_title: Great work environment but poor career support
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Charlottesville, VA
pros: The University is a fantastic place to do research. There is a deeply ingrained collaborative culture at UVA. Well-funded and well supported.
cons: Poor support for career minded post-doctoral associates/fellows. Great on research but really only train future academic researcher and even then, tend to only teach them the science side and not the administrative side which would be the most substantive part of anyones career when they begin to run a lab.

review_title: Could be great if you had a good manager
pros: The university tries to make it a good place to work. There are several events throughout the year that were intended to increase morale.
cons:
Pay is terrible, but that is common in academia.
Although the university as a whole appears to support employees, middle management is awful. My superiors were downright terrible.

pros: Good place to start as a graduate student. The faculties here are helpful and they are willing to sit there to help you.
cons: Location is very poor, It is so far away from New york city. It takes 2 hours drive to the DC. So many cars in the small town. The infrastructure is poor.

pros: You get to work with great people and you learn some valuable skills in the telemarketing space. Great bosses and coworkers. Fair salary for the job.
cons: Not always the most pleasant work, getting hung up on can get frustrating. Room smells like dookie all the time for some reason or another.

pros: The Reslife program provides great training and tremendous support to their staff. RA's have a lot of resources at their disposal and the opportunity to influence the lives of many students.
cons: The program has been going through some changes in the last few years and a lot of things became more tedious than they needed to be. New rules seemed to be implemented for the entire program, despite the fact that they only made sense in a few areas.

review_title: Student- Current student of Economics in the College of Arts and Sciences
pros: The academic environment sets high standards. The professor expect a lot and most of the students rise to the challenge. Excellent professors. Beautiful campus. Excellent student life with highly involved student body.
cons: Everyone is so driven that it can be very stressful when you have a whole school of overachievers. Some professors set their standards impossibly high.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Charlottesville, and the University of Virginia Grounds are simply amazing, it is like working in a well-tended garden. Some of the most talented people, and extremely helpful staff/faculty/students. Great research equipment and most of the time through collaboration there is access to just about any multimillion dollar equipment any researcher could dream of.
cons: There are some feuds among the faculty. This requires some political tact.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Charlottesville, VA
pros:
Nice academic environment. Professors willing to give time to you.
Charlottesville is a great town to spend 6-7 years completing your degree in.
cons: Can be competitive sometimes especially among graduate students. Some professors have issues with each other so you have to be careful not to be caught in the middle. They are also becoming exeedingly stingy with funding

review_title: It has been a exciting, challenging, and rewarding (and also full of bumps) road
pros:
Very knowledgeable faculty and researchers

State of the art facilities

Collaborative and multidisciplinary environment

Many opportunities for professional development
cons:
Stipend can be low, specially if you are fully independent and have to pay some student loans.  Stipend also varies from department to department.

Not all the students leave the program with a job.  Need to make sure your adviser have good contacts

review_title: Good place to be a graduate student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: I like having all the resources that are available to graduate students at UVa. The research that I conducted is well funded, and we are encouraged to obtain external funding as well.
cons: Sometimes the facilities that really need to be updated (such as research labs) are not. Instead money is dedicated to updating undergraduate student areas, that will make the buildings look great to potential students.

job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Charlottesville, VA
pros:
Largest employer in Charlottesville
Bleeding-edge tech
Advancement opportunities
cons:
Extreme work stress (100 hour weeks, once was necessary for me to be there 36 hours straight without sleep during a crisis)
Very poor management starting at CIO and going all the way down to middle management
Project manager-heavy organization, many PMs and not enough engineers
Very poor HR (contacted HR about work stress and was not given aid, HR completely sided with management in toxic situations)
Unclear technical direction
Extreme level of projects per engineer
Allows largest projects and responsibilities to fall on very few high quality engineers
Low level of competence and morale around campus in general but especially within ITS

job_title: Circulation Desk Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: You got to do all the homework here and still got paid by hours. It is a pretty flexible and easy job for students here.
cons: Charlottesville is not interesting at all if you come from a huge city like. Life is kinda boring and after one year you just can't wait to leave.

pros: UVA has great resources partly because of a dedicated alumni base. I worked with really wonderful people who valued teamwork, and my boss at UVA was the best boss I ever had or will ever have.
cons: The department I worked for wasn't well funded. Upper-level leadership was going through some growing pains. There was a poor work/life balance due to upper-level leadership.

pros:
Once hired, never fired.
Collegial
Education benefit.
cons: * Incentives for doing better are minimal -- the pay scale is banded and any raises or promotions you might get allow for only an incremental increase in money. So be warned: the salary at which you enter U.Va. will haunt you for the rest of your career at U.Va.

review_title: Great opportunity to meet and work with education researchers.
pros: The chance to interact with researchers to learn and use cutting edge education research to help teachers solve classroom problems was professionally both stimulating and satisfying.
cons: While some supervisors can be supportive, others can be insensitive or neglectful. The salary was on the low side and hard to live on with a family. The benefits, however, were excellent.

pros: There was a good work/life balance, The benefits were good, I had a flexible schedule, and was able to telecommute
cons: The pay was very low and was not competitive in the department I worked for. Not the most progressive or forward thinking place to work.

review_title: Great place to work in Charlottesville
pros: For some careers, there's a lot of advancement potential; good pay and benefits for area; good job security
cons: Outgoing senior management seem to have lost their way; sometimes there is more focus on tradition and doing things the same way than on finding new solutions

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: The engineering school has latest technologies for research. The faculty is well respected and there is a lot to learn from them
cons: The attitude towards graduate students is very orthodox and conservative. They are not encouraged to take courses from other schools such as arts and management.

pros: The University of Virginia is a great place to work as a s student employee. Students have many opportunities to get involved within the University in a way that is productive for their personal and professional growth.
cons: I was very happy working for the University of Virginia. It is difficult to move up I suppose but I was working as a student with no intention to permanently work for the University.

pros: Excellent environment for being a professor! Supportive caring community. Although the research expectations are slightly out of line with the research support.
cons: The research expectations are slightly out of line with the research support. I'd probably look into the pressure on professors to be excellent in both teaching and research. And of course service.

pros: Free meals. Great HR, Flik is a pretty good company outside of Darden. Free wifi. 1 free beverage per day. Cross- training available.
cons: Poor leadership. The Benefits are eh.  The pay is wha? Parking fee taken out of every paycheck. $700+ yearly easy. Bratty academic culture , inconsistent yearly schedule. Pay for your uniform rental.

review_title: I got great training and good teaching experience.
pros: I like communicating with students. My colleagues and professors are super nice. I feel good when sharing knowledge with other people.
cons: Teaching is a little distracting from doing research. Some students complain on grading but the main reason is they don't study hard.

review_title: Great place to work -- depending on whoever runs it
pros: Enjoyable work environment, quiet. Usually a lot of things to work around like collecting documents and such. Otherwise a very quiet time. Not too bad.
cons: Maybe too quiet. Depending on the time of year and the number of clients you could just be sitting there listening to music for a couple of hours when you're working in the lab.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Friendly and the program is good
cons: The engineering school in this university did not receive much support from the Vistor Board, as they favor Business and Law schools more. And more job opportunities are governmental contracts, so international students do not have many chances.

review_title: Good place to be a grad
pros: Decent benefits, good culture, awesome and diverse atudent population, great opportunities at an R3 school
cons: Grad student pay is at best par, work hour expectation can be crazy. You know, the usual grad student things.

review_title: Great school. Degrees from UVA carry value.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: I met many of intelligent, amazing people who were very driven to accomplish their goals. There are many people who are interested in forming lasting professional and social networks throughout many industries. Degrees from UVA are well respected.
cons: An elitist culture seems to permeate through the campus. This culture can be a little off-putting to certain types of people from certain backgrounds or life experiences.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Stimulating environment, lots of people to exchange ideas with. You get to know about the latest research in different fields.
cons:
Miserable salaries (grad students are officially paid to work for 20 hours per week but they work more than the double!)
Some professors are very paper oriented, they won't try to solve a research problem which won't lead to many papers.

pros: great people (both professors and your fellow grad students), welcoming atmosphere, state-of-the-art facilities, very friendly and prompt staff, beautiful campus, good social vibe in the department;
cons: My main problem was that as a grad student you cannot meet many people outside of your own department's bubble but that must be true almost everywhere anyway.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Nice small town environment, nice weather for much of the year, lots of outdoor activities, good place to raise kids
cons: Very few options for jobs here outside of academia for people with advanced degrees. Not much room for advancement in academic positions either, and the pay is lower than average. Cons with being a postdoctoral research associate are the typical ones you find for being a contract worker.

review_title: Good University to study and work
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Nice faculty and staff members. Charlottesville is a very pleasant place for living. 2 hrs driving to DC. Nice weather.
cons: low salary for staff members. Research facilities are not state of the art. Collaborations between departments are not very strong

pros: Great benefits package. The retirement is awesome.
cons: Micro management to the max. They tell you they want thinkers, pro active people and then handcuff you. They don't believe a first line. Supervisor should work or support their troops. Management is too busy worrying about what people will think than actually enforcing laws!

review_title: Amazingly diverse and well-rounded education with great research opportunities
pros: Great location with good weather and excellent work environment and culture
cons: Not as global a community as it claims to be, and somewhat removed from the action in D.C., NYC, and other big Northeast cities.

review_title: Wonderful work environment and learning curve
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros:
Mentors always available and willing to help when you ask/look for them. 
Learning curve is great, initiative has to be taken.
cons: HR is a pain in general, but the new workday system has helped. Other than that, not many cons in the lab unless you are set up with a PI that has unreasonable expectations and puts too much pressure on his students.

review_title: I am very satisfied with the graduate tenure at UVa
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: They gave me good training with a lot of workshops, counseling. Every one are very nice and polite. The environment is very cozy
cons: The city is a bit boring if you want to find a good network. And it is not a big hub of working network.

pros: Excellent school with great reputation. A lot of professional development activities outside of just obtaining your graduate degree. Excellent area to live.
cons: Very hard to get a job offer in Charlottesville. Will have to move to find a job in most areas. School has a difficult time recruiting large companies to come recruit in the area.

review_title: Great job, ok pay, lots of perks, descent benefits.
job_title: Trades Utility Senior in Charlottesville, VA
pros: This is been a good stable job and I have enjoyed working here. I could make more money doing construction as I used to but it would be a lot harder work.
cons: The health-care benefits are not as good as they used to be and most people could make quite a bit more money working in the private sector.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros: This is a great place for grad school. A small town with all you need, and people are really nice.
cons: Charlottesville is a bit boring for me - probably the same for you if you are coming from a big city.

pros: Consistent work-life balance (best I've ever experienced), kind and supportive coworkers, beautiful campus, excellent benefits, meaningful work, opportunities for professional development
cons: UVA is highly decentralized; some processes are inefficient and slow; there are few opportunities for raises/promotion compared to the private sector

review_title: UVA  SOM Neurosurgery and Neuro Oncology
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Ok benefits, lots of time off, interesting work
cons: Poor culture, doctors and most coworkers are bullies and not very pleasant to work with (miserable).

review_title: A real community feeling, unusual for a top business school
pros: Unparalleled commitment to the classroom environment and teaching quality.  Great location if you're not a big city person.  Smart and dedicated students.  Great facilities.  Mission - Develop principled leaders in the world of practical affairs.
cons: Research productivity is very important for faculty, but teaching standards are also very high (compared to other places).

pros: I really have flourished in my position over the past three years working at UVA HRL. You are always supported in everything you do.
cons: I do not have any cons. Sometimes, the structures have changed of things I had been used to but the changes actually made things a lot easier.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Charlottesville, VA
pros:
Work culture is excellent
Learning experience is valauable
Many useful networking opportunities with alumni and company relationships
cons:
Insurance lacks dental and eye coverage
Engineering school needs to market itself better as it is highly underrated, particularly its graduate programs
